subsections.name: Interactive maps?
subsections.text: Make your project browsable, navigable, and exciting! Visualise relationships, notice patterns, or share information. Make use of the wealth of public information on OpenStreetMap and other sources.

subsections.name: Data science and visualisation?
subsections.text: Explore your datasets, fit models, and extract meaning from complexity. Display your information so it's clear and attention-grabbing. Use modern machine learning where appropriate, or classical statistical methods.

subsections.name: Cartography?
subsections.text: Capture the spatial aspect of your project in beautiful, clear, information-rich maps. Include the latest remote-sensing datasets including satellite imagery and digital elevation models.. Inform your strategy.

subsections.name: Custom pipelines?
subsections.text: Add to your existing data architecture, create a new workflow, or build a tool that your team can use, or which your customers can interact with.

subsections.name: Oxford University WildCRU
subsections.text: I built the WildMAPS Species Distribution Model dashboard. This owner-updatable catalog of raster data is a research tool for ecologists worldwide. It’s built to display big files (100s of gigabytes) smoothly, with a low hosting cost (pennies per week).

subsections.name: NHS psychiatrists
subsections.text: I processed more than five million rows of mental-health reporting, for a group of NHS (UK National Health Service) psychiatrists trying to understand how different restraint methods are used. The results and visualisations revealed severe gaps in reporting, and were published in BJPsych Bulletin.

subsections.name: Hydrogen explorers
subsections.text: (For confidentiality reasons, no specific details are given.) In a soil-gas survey, I planned survey locations, collected field data, coordinated teams, and plotted results, to determine the prospectivity of a target region.

subsections.name: Oxford University SalGo Team
subsections.text: The SalGo Team were locked in to an expensive subscription for the map on the homepage of their plant and animal database (COMPADRE/COMADRE). In a day's work, I swapped it out for a permanent, free, improved solution, integrating with their existing PHP backend.

subsections.name: Education
subsections.text:
BA, MSci (physics, minor geology) University of Cambridge.
PhD (seismology) Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
I’m trained as a scientist, with subject knowledge in physics, mathematics, statitistics, geology, and scientific computing.

subsections.name: Humanitarian disaster response
subsections.text: I'm a deployable geospatial volunteer for MapAction, with over seven weeks of emergency response experience, including field missions in Myanmar and Mozambique.

subsections.name: Scientific fieldwork
subsections.text: I've done than 21 weeks of geological and geophysical fieldwork in Europe, the Americas, and India, including: six weeks of solo mapping in Jamaica, and leading a gravity survey in Saint Lucia.

subsections.name: More skills
subsections.text: See my full CV for other skills: programming and GIS tools, spoken languages, teaching, writing, and even long-distance hiking, if you need trail maps...

subsections.name: Top quality
subsections.text: I take pride in my products, and I'm just as invested as you in the quality of the result.

subsections.name: Free, open tools that save you money
subsections.text: Don't get locked in to expensive contracts! Free software is now powerful enough for any geospatial task. No recurring bills, and no software overheads from me.

subsections.name: Efficiency
subsections.text: We'll agree a timeframe, and I can get things done fast!

subsections.name: Communication and iteration
subsections.text: I'm a good communicator and I'll iterate the product with you to make sure you get what you want. So... get in touch! Email me, Harry, at: projects@HKuril.com
